Text.Text: What are yeh doin' in me home?  Away with yeh!  Away, I say!
Git!  I dinnae ask for yer help!  Git ye gone!
What are yeh doin' in me home?  Away with yeh!
Ha!  So he sent ye rather than dragging his mangy hide to my door, did he?!  Likely story!  Out, out, afore I cane yer hide from here ta Bremen, ye filthy robbers!
Oh, is that so?  Well, then I'm certain as the Dale is cold that it'll please yeh to leave me home!  Out, out, afore I cane yer hide from here ta Bremen, ye filthy robbers!
Ach, yeh're back?!  I thought I told yeh to leave me alone... now away with yeh, ye filthy robbers!
Eh?  Wh-?  How DARE ye -
Now ye look 'ere!  I dinnae ASK ye t-
I won't 'ear such words spoken in me own home!  Git!  Git ye gone!

"The Wicked Wench?!"  Are ye telling me that Hedron, that shifty lice-ridden crag cat, can't even be troubled to step off his ship to save his own Ma?!  I regret the day I squeezed that boy out, I do!

"The Wicked Wench?!"  That's me son's ship!  Why, Hedron, that shifty lice-ridden crag cat, can't even be troubled to step off his ship to save his own Ma!  I regret the day I squeezed that boy out, I do!
Hmmph.  Ye'd best go tell him I'm all right, then.  He might git to worrying, he would, and then he starts drinking, and after that, well, there's just more suffering, so there is.
Hmmph.  Then ye'd best go tell him I'm all right, then.  He might git to worrying, he would, and then he starts drinking, and after that, well, there's just more suffering, so there is.
Hmmmph.  Yer back, are ye?  Ye circle me house like a vulture, ye do.
As if that filthy cur would shed two coppers for me!  Just because I've got the ache of age in me bones, and the winds have taken me eyes don't mean that I can't look after meself?
Pah!  Stop mothering me and git on!  Just because I've got the ache of age in me bones, and the winds have taken me eyes don't mean that I can't look after meself?
Aye, but don't think I'm so blind I didn't see ye lift that gold from under my own roof, ye little thief.  I let ye keep it out of respect for dealing death to those goblins.

Aye, but don't think I'm so blind I didn't see ye lift that gold from under my own roof, ye little thief.  I let ye keep it out of respect for dealing death to those goblins - but shame on ye, some holy warrior of virtue ye are!
Are ye deaf?!  I said keep it, and ye'll insult me twice if ye try to give that tainted gold back to me.
Ye've got a tongue and half the mind to match.  Little wonder that fool Hedron took ye on board his leaky boat.
These eyes do more than see, they do, and ye'd best remember that.  I see more than ye'll EVER see, and I hear all that blows in the shores of Maer Dualdon.

Aye, I've heard that tale.  It tells of the pain that comes when we forget the beauty and the feeling of being human.  It is all in what ye see, and I've seen more than *ye'll* ever hope to in the shadows of Targos.

Not now, there's still goblin lives waiting to have their threads cut short on the shores of Maer Dualdon.  Come back when ye've cleared the blighters from the Docks, and ye and I will speak again... *iffen* the mood takes me.

Hmmph.  I was wondering when ye might git around to picking me skull - ye didn't seem bright enough to light a candle, ye didn't.  Ask away if ye will, but I rarely leave me home, much less talk to any of the fools in Targos, so my talk may not be much use.
There's a hundred stories in Targos, there is, maybe a hundred upon hundred.  What would ye be burning to know?  I've not the strength to tell them all.

The filthy little rats started chipping at Targos a month or two ago, and the attack on the Docks is the bravest they've been yet, it is.  But there's worse yet to come, much worse, mark me words.  I can feel a storm coming, and it's building up out of the North like a howling pack of wolves.

The filthy little rats started chipping at Targos a month or two ago, and the attack on the Palisade is the bravest they've been yet, it is.  But there's worse yet to come, much worse, mark me words.  I can feel a storm coming, and it's building up out of the North like a howling pack of wolves.
Aye, ye can rest at the Weeping Widow, ye can, but 'ware ye the innkeeper, Cahl-Hyred.  Twice the fool he may be, but he'll try to milk ye like a cow of any offer of help.

So don't let the blustering fool use ye like a pack mule without getting coin in return.  He'd bleed a paladin dry of his last drop of patience he would, and he'll do the same to ye, mark me words.  Take a look through his eyes, and ye'll see a world raining gold coins.

Ye can find the trade depot at the top o' the cliffs, ye can.  The strip of the girl there, Deirdre's got a heart like a fire, but ye should be able to find what ye need there.  Just don't press her too hard, or ye'll liable to catch trouble for your efforts.

Her drunkard of a Grand-Da, that old wheezing fool Ilmus, sent her to Targos to prove herself to the rest of the Gallaway Coster.  When the goblins struck Targos, it ruined her chances of turning profit - and ruined her name with it.  Ye can almost hear the storm clouds building in her head.

Make fast friends with Ulbrec's wife, the elven woman.  She's a sharp one, she is - her eyes and thoughts are like ice, cold and sharp, but her heart has a kind bent, like the dawn of a spring morning.  Her heart is in Targos, and ye can trust her.

Snap up any weapons ye can find, for ye'll be needing 'em right quick - arrows, stones, bolts, all will be your friends in days to come.  Talk before ye act, even with those ye think might be your foes.  Your journey is a long one, and Targos is just the first step on a difficult road.
Tales of the Dale?  Ha!  There's so many tales that'd fill up Dualdon, there is, and most-like twice over.  Not much that would whet yer appetite, me thinks.
Not much to tell.  Most of the towns squabble over knucklehead trout and skulk indoors when the cold's too much to bear.  But... hmmm.

There *was* the troubles many years back, though, back when Hedron was a babe and his Da - curse his hide - still dared to live.   Hmmph.  That was perhaps the worst times we've had... though it could be it was just Hedron's Da that was the cause of it all.
Aye, I'll tell ye, but I'll only tell ye once, so ye'd best listen close - or else get yer pen and write it in that book ye're carrying with ye.
...and then the barbarians packed up their tents and left Bremen's Run, they did.  And that's the last of the matter - at least as far as the barbarians were concerned.
Aye, gods only know what happened after that.  There was something evil in that halfling's tread, to be sure, and I'm sure it led those heroes nowhere good.
Aye, well... just a feeling in my bones.  I've learned to trust the lean of the winds and the ache in me joints.
Ye watch yer filthy tongue, I don't need t'explain meself to the likes of ye - an' don't ye *dare* compare me to one of those filthy barbarians, the winds take ye.
Pah! I don't need t'explain meself to the likes of ye - believe me or not, it's no matter t'me.
Mayhap... there's times... nay, ye'd think me daft like the rest of the town.
Eh?  What are ye on about?
Mayhap... I see things.  What business be it of yours?
There's times when I sleep, when I sleep not, and the things I see in dreams, they're more real than the walls of me house.  Some things... some are beautiful.  Others - terrible.
I... I see... I've *seen* a brambled garden, blacker than ink, a crow's nest of a city that spins atop a great mast of stone, and a glacier of black ice - ice that smells of ashes and smoke.

But that's not the strangest thing... I see these things, but it's not *me* who's seeing them, but it's always through another's eyes, a woman's eyes, I see these... these other lives, all a-colored gray and sadness, branching outwards - like some great black, twisted tree.

If t'isn't poor Loki... that fool cat looks to have eaten twice his weight, he has - a dozen rats, by the smell of it.  That damned old tom ran away nearly a month ago - at least he died happy, he did.
He did *what?*  Stole one of my pretties, did he?!  I'll spear a dozen curses on his head until he can't walk straight!  I'll bring the night of the thousand cats upon his head!
Aye - as soon as ye get the poor thing outta me sight.  Have ye no shame, hauling around a poor dead cat like that?
Says ye!  Now get the poor thing outta me sight.  Have ye no shame, hauling around poor dead Loki like that?

Oh, nay, it's *not* too late for a devils' due.  What be the filthy thief's name?  Anson?  A blustering fool who sits around the campfire and thinks of rutting every hole he sees, is he?  Two shadows travel with him... Tarran... and Illigmar - under the sign of crossed spears.
I know what tiny thoughts rattle in his skull, I do, and I'll see him suffer - only then will my heart be satisfied.

Aye, the great oak of Kuldahar - I know of that tree, I do, an' it's sure as the snows it's mixed up in this darkening cloud over the North... there is something about such a work of nature that no beast or devil can leave be... and great evils have been done in its shadow.
Hmmph.  Yer right - Loki died with a full belly, at the least.  No matter.  Everything has its time, and Anson's only crime is his foolishness.  There was no malice in it.
Aye, poor Loki went his way not long ago - probably curled up somewhere to die, poor old thing.

Mayhap ye'll find yer way there.  Mayhap not - but know the tree is *waiting* for ye, and it suffers.  The screams of a birthing woman echo in the wood of the oak, and I fear some terrible act has taken place there... either now, or long ago.
Aye, Targos waits... but enough of the ramblings of an old woman.  Have ye any more questions for me?
Are ye telling me that Hedron, that shifty lice-ridden crag cat, can't even be troubled to step off his ship to save his own Ma?!  I regret the day I squeezed that boy out, I do!
Are you Firtha?  Your son, Hedron, asked us to check on you - and it looks like we came just in time.
We're trying to help you, woman!
So we should just leave you to the goblins then?
You're going to have our help whether you like it or not, crone.  Now sit down and curb your tongue!
Whether you wish our help or not, we're going to deal with these goblins.
Are you Firtha?  Your son, Hedron, asked us to check on you - and it looks like we came just in time.
Please - calm down, we just had some questions.
I will take my leave, then.  Farewell.
We're *not* robbers.  We just sailed in on the Wicked Wench to aid Targos.
Look, you filthy banshee, enough of your howling, or we WILL rob you.
Is *this* the thanks you offer to those who saved your life?  We come to your aid, and you repay us with threats?!
Please - calm down, we just had some questions.
I will take my leave, then.  Farewell.
Are you Firtha?  Your son, Hedron, asked us to check on you - and it looks like we came just in time.
We're *not* robbers.  We just sailed in on the Wicked Wench to aid Targos.
Look, you filthy banshee, enough of your howling, or we WILL rob you.
Is *this* the thanks you offer to those who saved your life?  We come to your aid, and you repay us with threats?!
I will take my leave, then.  Farewell.
Are you Firtha?  Your son, Hedron, asked us to check on you - and it looks like we came just in time.
We're *not* robbers.  We just sailed in on the Wicked Wench to aid Targos.
Please - calm down, we just had some questions.
I will take my leave, then.  Farewell.
Be *silent.*  I've heard enough from you - we came and saved your life, and you offer no word of thanks, no appreciation?
Your lack of gratitude shames your family name... and cuts me deeper than any goblin's blade.
We'll head back to the Wicked Wench, then.  Farewell.
There is nothing more to be said.  Farewell.
Did your mother teach you nothing of manners, so much that you spit upon an offered hand of help?
I hope you show more respect to the next group that stands between you and death.  Farewell.
We'll head back to the Wicked Wench, then.  Farewell.
There is nothing more to be said.  Farewell.
Nothing would please me more.  Farewell.
We'll head back to the Wicked Wench, then.  Farewell.
There is nothing more to be said.  Farewell.
Uh, squeezed out, I see.  Interesting way to put it.
Hedron will probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
You're Hedron's mother? If so, he'd probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
Uh, squeezed out, I see.  Interesting way to put it.
Hedron will probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
You're Hedron's mother? If so, he'd probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
Before I go, are you sure you're all right?
Hedron will soon know you're all right - and perhaps he'll be a bit more thankful than you.  Farewell.
We'll let him know then.  Farewell, Firtha.
Before I go, are you sure you're all right?
Hedron will soon know you're all right - and perhaps he'll be a bit more thankful than you.  Farewell.
We'll let him know then.  Farewell, Firtha.
We told your son that you were all right.
We just wanted to check and make sure you're all right.
Is this cat yours?  We found it dead in the warehouse in the northern side of town.
Are you missing a cat, Firtha?  We heard one of your cats had gone missing.
We found out what happened to your cat Loki, Firtha.  Turns out one of the mercenaries at the Palisade kidnapped him and dumped him in the warehouse to drive out the rats.
I wanted to ask you some questions.
I wanted to ask you some questions.
Can you tell me anything about Targos?
I'd like to know whatever you can tell me about Icewind Dale.
I will take my leave, then.  Farewell.
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
You're blind?
You're blind?
You're blind?
Well, at least you still have your damnable cats.  Good riddance, woman.
I must take my leave.  Farewell.
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
"The wind took my eyes?"  What do you mean?
You're blind?
You're blind?
You're blind?
Well, at least you still have your damnable cats.  Farewell.
Sorry about that.  Please accept my apologies.
Oh that gold was yours?  I thought one of your cats had dropped it.
Uh... well, I assumed you'd let me keep it, so it wasn't really stealing.
One of my band has acted shamefully, and I will see to it they are punished and your gold is returned.
You have shamed me, indeed.  We did not intend to rob you.  I will return what I stole.
Very well, then.  I did not realize you had seen us help ourselves to your belongings.
Very well, then.  I did not realize you had seen us help ourselves to your belongings.
"Eyes do more than see?"  That reminds me of a tale I heard from a bard in the South.
"Eyes do more than see?"  That reminds me of a tale I heard from a bard in the South.
Like what do you see?
Then perhaps you could answer some questions for me.
Then perhaps you could answer some questions for me.
Like what do you see?
Then perhaps you could answer some questions for me.
Then perhaps you could answer some questions for me.
Very well.  We shall return when the docks are clear of goblins.
Is this cat yours?  We found it dead in the warehouse in the northern side of town.
Are you missing a cat, Firtha?  We heard one of your cats had gone missing.
We found out what happened to your cat Loki, Firtha.  Turns out one of the mercenaries at the Palisade kidnapped him and dumped him in the warehouse to drive out the rats.
Can you tell me anything about Targos?
I'd like to know whatever you can tell me about Icewind Dale.
Perhaps we'll leave the questions for another time.  Farewell.
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
Is there any place in town we can rest?
Can you tell us where to purchase supplies?
Any advice to newcomers in town?
Never mind about Targos, then.  Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
Sorry to disturb you, then.  Farewell.
How do you know that?
Is there any place in town we can rest?
Can you tell us where to purchase supplies?
Any advice to newcomers in town?
Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
I see.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
A coming storm?  How do you know that?
Is there any place in town we can rest?
Can you tell us where to purchase supplies?
Any advice to newcomers in town?
Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
I see.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
Really?  And how do you know what Cahl-Hyred sees?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
Can you tell us where to purchase supplies?
Any advice to newcomers in town?
Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
I see.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
What do you mean?
Storm clouds in her head?  How do you know that?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
Is there any place in town we can rest?
Any advice to newcomers in town?
Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
I see.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
The first step?  How do you know that?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
What can you tell me about the goblin raiders?
Is there any place in town we can rest?
Do you know any tales of Icewind Dale?
I see.  Thanks for the information.  Farewell.
Well then, can you tell me anything about the Ten-Towns?
I heard the Dale had some troubles many years back.  Do you know anything about that?
Could you tell me anything about these troubles?
I'll copy your story into my journal, then.  Please, go ahead.
So the adventurers were never heard from again after that night in the Whistling Gallows Inn?
I see.  Can you tell me anything about Targos?
Very well.  Thanks for the tale, Firtha.
That's the response I'd expect from an Uthgart Seer casting fortunes.
That's awfully specific information to be a hunch, especially if you don't leave your house much or speak to many people in town.
There's no way you could know that from a feeling in your bones.
But how *do* you know those things?
How *do* you know those things?
Are you sure you don't have any barbarian blood in you?  Some of the women of the barbarian tribes are said to have the gift of Sight, especially ones blind to the waking world.
Are you sure you don't have any barbarian blood in you?  Some of the women of the barbarian tribes are said to have the gift of Sight, especially ones blind to the waking world.
Are you sure barbarian blood doesn't run in your veins?  Some of the women of my tribe had the gift of Sight, especially ones blind to the waking world.
No, I want to hear it.  Go on.
As long it doesn't involve your cats, I'm willing to hear it.
Do you ever see things in your dreams?  Or have visions during the day of what people are thinking, of things that are to come, but you can't quite remember?
What do you see?
A tree?  In Luskan, I heard tales of a great tree in the town of Kuldahar.
I... see.  What can you tell me of Targos?
Can you tell me anything about Icewind Dale?
Actually, one of the mercenaries stole him and dumped him in the warehouse to clear out the rats.
I'm sorry, Firtha.  Are you going to be all right?
Well, it looks like you needed the space.  One more cat in your house isn't going to make a difference.
He meant no harm to the cat, Firtha - and to be honest, your cat looks like he dined well before he died.  It's too late for curses now.
He wronged you, Firtha, but there's little to be done about it now.
Actually, one of the mercenaries stole him and dumped him in the warehouse to clear out the rats.
Never mind, then.  Can you tell me anything about Targos?
We'll let the matter rest, then.  I'd like to know whatever you can tell me about Icewind Dale.
We must take our leave.  Farewell.
Actually, one of the mercenaries stole him and dumped him in the warehouse to clear out the rats.
Never mind, then.  Can you tell me anything about Targos?
We'll let the matter rest, then.  I'd like to know whatever you can tell me about Icewind Dale.
We must take our leave.  Farewell.
How did you know his name was Anson?  And what company he served with?
Anson doesn't deserve that, Firtha.  Do not throw curses about lightly, especially while the goblins threaten Targos.
If you know what thoughts rattle in Anson's skull, you know he meant no harm.  And Loki's death was his own doing - that cat's eyes were bigger than his mouth.
How did you know his name was Anson?  And what company he served with?
We'll let the matter rest, then.  Can you tell me anything about Targos?
Can I ask you some questions about Icewind Dale?
We must take our leave.  Farewell.
Actually, one of the mercenaries stole him and dumped him in the warehouse to clear out the rats.
Never mind, then.  Can you tell me anything about Targos?
We'll let the matter rest, then.  I'd like to know whatever you can tell me about Icewind Dale.
We must take our leave.  Farewell.
I see.  Well, we have no plans to go to Kuldahar - perhaps when our duty in Targos is over.
What can you tell me of Targos?
Can you tell me anything about Icewind Dale?
Nothing more, Firtha.  Rest, and we may return.
Uh, squeezed out, I see.  Interesting way to put it.
Hedron will probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
You're Hedron's mother? If so, he'd probably like to know that you're safe... I think.
